Which I would as a principle leave to all,
That make their maintenance out of their own Indies
As I do now; my good old mother taught me,
Daughter, quoth she, contest not with your lover
His stomach being empty; let wine heat him,
And than you may command him: 'tis a sure one:
His looks show he is coming.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Come this needs not,
Especially to me: you know how dear
I ever have esteemed you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Lost again.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: That any sight of yours, hath power to change
My strongest resolution, and one tear
Sufficient to command a pardon from me,
For any wrong from you, which all mankind
Should kneel in vain for.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Pray you pardon those
That need your favour, or desire it

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Prithee.
Be better tempered: I'll pay as a forfeit
For my rash anger, this purse filled with gold.
Thou shalt have servants, gowns, attires, what not?
Only continue mine.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'Twas this I fished for

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Look on me, and receive it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Well, you know
My gentle nature, and take pride t'abuse it:
You see a trifle pleases me, we are friends;
This kiss, and this confirms it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: With my ruin.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I'll have this diamond; and this pearl.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: They are yours.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But will you not, when you have what you came for,
Take them from me tomorrow? 'tis a fashion
Your lords of late have used.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: But I'll not follow.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: That any man at such a rate as this
Should pay for his repentance.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Shall we to bed now?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Instantly, sweet: yet now I think on't better
There's something first that in a word or two
I must acquaint you with.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Can I cry aim,
To this against myself? I'll break this match,
Or make it stronger with my blood. Descends.

div.stage: Enter Alguazier, Piorato, Pachieco, Metaldi, Mendoza, Lazarillo, etc.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: I am yours,
A don's not privileged here more than yourself,
Win her, and wear her.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: Have you a priest ready?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: I have him for thee, lad; and when I have
Married this scornful whore to this poor gallant.
She will make suit to me; there is a trick
To bring a high-prized wench upon her knees:
For you my fine neat harpies stretch your talons
And prove yourselves true night-birds.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: Take my word
For me and all the rest.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: If there be meat
Or any banquet stirring, you shall see
How I'll bestow myself.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: When they are drawn,
Rush in upon 'em: all's fair prize you light on:
I must away: your officer may give way
To the knavery of his watch, but must not see it.
You all know where to find me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: There look for us.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: My Piorato, welcome, welcome:
Faith had you not come when you did, my lord
Had done I know not what to me.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I am guled,
First cheated of my jewels, and then laughed at:
Sirrah, what make you here?

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: A business brings me,
More lawful than your own,

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: How's that, you slave?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: He's such, that would continue his a whore
Whom he would make a wife of.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I'll tread upon
The face you dote on, strumpet.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: Keep the peace there.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: A plot upon my life too?

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Down with him.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Show your old valour, and learn from a woman,
One eagle has a world of odds against
A flight of daws, as these are.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: Get you off,
I'll follow instantly.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Run for more help there. Exeunt all but Vit. and Clara.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Loss of my gold, and jewels, and the wench too
Afflicts me not so much, as th'having Clara
The witness of my weakness.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: He turns from me,
And yet I may urge merit, since his life
Is made my second gift.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: May I ne'er prosper
If I know how to thank her.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Sir, your pardon
For pressing thus beyond a virgin's bounds
Upon your privacies: and let my being
Like to a man, as you are, be th'excuse
Of my soliciting that from you, which shall not
Be granted on my part, although desired
By any other: sir, you understand me,
And 'twould show nobly in you, to prevent
From me a farther boldness, which I must
Proceed in, if you prove not merciful,
Though with my loss of blushes, and good name.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Madam, I know your will, and would be thankful
If it were possible I could affect
The daughter of an enemy.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: That fair false one
Whom with fond dotage you have long pursued
Had such a father: she to whom you pay
Dearer for your dishonour, than all titles
Ambitious men hunt for are worth.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: 'Tis truth.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Yet, with her, as a friend you still exchange
Health for diseases, and to your disgrace
Nourish the rivals to your present pleasures,
At your own charge, used as a property
To give a safe protection to her lust,
Yet share in nothing but the shame of it.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Grant all this so, to take you for a wife
Were greater hazard, for should I offend you
(As 'tis not easy still to please a woman)
You are of so great a spirit, that I must learn
To wear your petticoat, for you will have
My breeches from me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Rather from this hour
I here abjure all actions of a man,
And will esteem it happiness from you
To suffer like a woman: love, true love
Hath made a search within me, and expelled
All but my natural softness, and made perfect
That which my parents care could not begin.
I will show strength in nothing, but my duty,
And glad desire to please you, and in that
Grow every day more able.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Could this be,
What a brave race might I beget? I find
A kind of yielding; and no reason why
I should hold longer out: she's young, and fair,
And chaste for sure, but with her leave the devil
Durst not attempt her: madam, though you have
A soldier's arm, your lips appear as if
They were a lady's.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: They dare sir from you
Endure the trial.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Ha: once more I pray you:
The best I ever tasted; and 'tis said
I have proved many, 'tis not safe I fear
To ask the rest now: well, I will leave whoring
And luck herein send me with her: worthiest lady,
I'll wait upon you home, and by the way
(If ere I many, as I'll not forswear it)
Tell you, you are my wife.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Which if you do,
From me all mankind women, learn to woe. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Alguazier, Pachieco, Metaldi, Mendoza, Lararillo.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: A cloak? good purchase, and rich hangers? well,
We'll share ten pistolets a man

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Yet still
I am monstrous hungry: could you not deduct
So much out of the gross some, as would purchase
Eight loins of veal, and some two dozen of capons?

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: O strange proportion for five.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: For five? I have
A legion in my stomach that have kept
Perpetual fast these ten years: for the capons,
They are to me but as so many black birds:
May I but eat once, and be satisfied,
Let the fates call me, when my ship is fraught,
And I shall hang in peace.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: Steal well tonight ,
And thou shalt feed tomorrow; so now you are
Yourselves again, I'll raise another watch
To free you from suspicion: set on any
You meet with boldly: I'll not be far off,
T'assist you, and protect you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: O brave officer.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: Would every ward had one but so well given,
And we would watch for rug, in gowns of velvet.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: Stand close: a prize.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Satin, and gold lace, lads.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Why dost thou hang upon me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Tis so dark
I dare not see my way: for heaven's sake father
Let us go home.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: No, e'en here we'll leave you:
Let's run away from him, my lord.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O alas.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Thou hast made me mad: and I will beat thee dead
Then bray thee in a mortar, and now mould thee
But I will alter thee.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: 'Twill never be:
He has been three days practising to drink,
Yet still he sips, like to a waiting woman,
And looks as he were murdering of a fart
Among wild Irish swaggerers.

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.l: I have still
Your good word, Zancho, father.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Milksop coward;
No house of mine receives thee: I disclaim thee,
Thy mother; on her knees shall not entreat me
Hereafter to acknowledge thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pray you speak for me.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: I would; but now I cannot with mine honour.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: There's only one course left, that may redeem thee,
Which is, to strike the next man that you meet,
And if we chance to light upon a woman,
Take her away, and use her like a man,
Or I will cut thy hamstrings.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: This makes for us

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: What dost thou do now?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir, I am saying my prayers;
For being to undertake what you would have me,
I know I cannot live.

div.stage: Enter Lamorall, Genevora, Anastro, and pages with lights.

sp.speaker: Lam
sp.l: Madam, I fear
You'll wish you had used your coach: your brother's house
Is yet far off.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: The better sir: this walk
Will help digestion after your great supper,
Of which I have fed largely.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: To your task,
Or else you know what follows:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am dying:
Now lord have mercy on me: by your favour,
Sir I must strike you.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: For what cause?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I know not:
And I must likewise talk with that young lady,
An hour in private.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: What you must, is doubtful,
But I am certain sir, I must beat you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Help, help.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Not strike again?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How, Alvarez?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: This for my lord Vitell's love.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: Break out,
And like true thieves, make pray on either side,
But seem to help the stranger.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: O my lord,
They have beat him on his knees.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Though I want courage:
I yet have a son's duty in me, and
Compassion of a father's danger; that,
That wholly now possesses me.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Lucio.
This is beyond my hope.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: So Lazarillo,
Take up all boy: well done.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: And now steal off
Closely, and cunningly.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: How? have I found you?
Why gentlemen, are you mad, to make yourselves
A prey to rogues?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Would we were off.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: Thieves, thieves.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Defer our own contention: and down with them.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I'll make you sure.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: Now he plays the devil.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: This place is not for me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I'll follow her
Half of my penance is passed o'er. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Alguazier, Assistente and other watches.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: What noise?
What tumult's there? keep the King's peace I charge you.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: I am glad he's come yet.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: O, you keep good guard
Upon the city, when men of our rank
Are set upon in the streets.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: The assistance
Shall hear of't be assured.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And if he be
That careful governor he is reported,
You will smart for it.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: Patience, good signiors:
Let me survey the rascals: oh, I know them,
And thank you for them: they are pillfring rogues
Of Andaluzia, that have perused
All prisons in Castille: I dare not trust
The dungeon with them: no, I'll have them home
To my own house.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: We had rather go to prison.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: Had you so dog-holts? yes, I know you had:
You there would use your cunning fingers on
The simple locks; you would: but I'll prevent you.

sp.speaker: Lam
sp.l: My mistress lost? good night. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: Your son's gone to,
What should become of him?

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Come of him, what will:
Now he dares fight, I care not: I'll to bed:
Look to your prisoners Alguazier. Exit with Boba.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: All's cleared:
Droop not for one disaster: let us hug,
And triumph in our knaveries.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: This confirms
What was reported of him.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: 'Twas done bravely.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: I must a little glory in the means
We officers have, to play the knaves, and safely:
How we break through the toils, pitched by the law,
Yet hang up them that are far less delinquents:
A simple shopkeeper's carted for a bawd
For lodging (Though unwittingly) a smock-gamster:
Where, with rewards, and credit I have kept
Malroda in my house, as in a cloister,
Without taint, or suspicion.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: But suppose
The governor should know't?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: He? good gentleman,
Let him perplex himself with prying into
The measures in the market, and th'abuses
The day stands guilty of: the pillage of the night
Is only mine, mine own feesimple;
Which you shall hold from me, tenants at will,
And pay no rent for't.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: Admirable landlord.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: Now we'll go search the taverns, commit such
As we find drinking: and be drunk ourselves
With what we take from them: these silly wretches
Whom I for form's sake only have brought hither
Shall watch without, and guard us.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: And we will.
See you safe lodged, most worthy Alguazier,
With all of you his comrades.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: 'Tis the governor.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: We are betrayed?

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: My guard there: bind them fast:
How men in high place, and authority
Are in their lives and estimation wronged
By their subordinate ministers? yet such
They cannot but employ: wronged justice finding
Scarce one true servant in ten officers.
'T'xpostulate with you, were but to delay
Your crimes due punishment, which shall fall upon you
So speedily, and severely, that it shall
Fright others by th'example: and confirm
However corrupt officers may disgrace
Themselves, 'tis not in them to wrong their place.
Bring them away.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: We'll suffer nobly yet,
And like to Spanish gallants.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: And we'll hang so.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: I have no stomach to it: but I'll endeavour.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Nay you are rude; pray you forbear; your offer now
More than the breeding of a gentleman
Can give you warrant for.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Tis but to kiss you,
And think not I'll receive that for a favour
Which was enjoined me for a penance, lady.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: You have met a gentle confessor, and for once
(So men you will rest satisfied) I vouchsafe it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Rest satisfied with a kiss? why can a man
Desire more from a woman? is there any
Pleasure beyond it? may I never live
If I know what it is.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Sweet innocence.

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.l: What strange new motions do I feel? my veins
Burn with an unknown fire: in every part
I suffer alteration: I am poisoned,
Yet languish with desire again to taste it,
So sweetly it works on me.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: I ne'er saw
A lovely man, till now.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How can this be?
She is a woman, as my mother is,
And her I have kissed often, and brought off
My lips unscorched; yours are more lovely, lady,
And so should be less hurtful: pray you vouchsafe
Your hand, to quench the heat ta'en from your lip,
Perhaps that may restore me.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Willingly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The flame increases: if to touch you, burn thus,
What would more strict embraces do? I know not,
And yet methinks to die so; were to ascend
To heaven, through paradise.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: I am wounded too,
Though modesty forbids that I should speak
What ignorance makes him bold in: why do you fix
Your eyes so strongly on me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pray you stand still,
There is nothing else, that is worth the looking on:
I could adore you, lady.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Can you love me?

sp.speaker: Luo.
sp.l: To wait on you, in your chamber, and but touch
What you, by wearing it, have made divine,
Were such a happiness. I am resolved,
I'll sell my liberty to you for this glove,
And write myself your slave.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: On easier terms,
Receive it as a friend.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How! giving favour!
I'll have it with his heart.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: What will you do?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: As you are merciful, take my life rather.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Will you depart with't so?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Does that grieve you?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: I know not: but even now you appear valiant.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Twas to preserve my father: in his cause
I could be so again.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Not in your own? Kneel to thy rival and thine enemy?
Away unworthy creature, I begin
To hate myself, for giving entrance to
A good opinion of thee: for thy torment,
If my poor beauty be of any power,
Mayst thou dote on it desperately: but never
Presume to hope for grace, till thou recover
And wear the favour that was ravished from thee.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: He wears my head to then.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Poor fool, farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My womanish soul, which hitherto hath governed
This coward flesh, I feel departing from me;
And in me by her beauty is inspired
A new, and masculine one: instructing me
What's fit to do or suffer; powerful love
That hast with loud, and yet a pleasing thunder
Roused sleeping manhood in me, thy new creature,
Perfect thy work so that I may make known
Nature (Though long kept back) will have her own.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Can it be possible, that in six short hours
The subject still the same, so many habits
Should be removed? or this new Lucio, he
That yesternight was baffled and disgraced,
And thanked the man that did it, that then kneeled
And blubbered like a woman, should now dare
One term of honour seek reparation
For what he then appeared not capable of?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Such miracles, men that dare do injuries
Live to their shames to see, and for punishment
And scourge to their proud follies.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Prithee leave me:
Had I my page, or footman here to flesh thee,
I durst the better hear thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: This scorn needs not:
And offer such no more.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Why say I should,
You'll not be angry?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Indeed I think I shall,
Would you vouchsafe to show yourself a captain,
And lead a little further, to some place
That's less frequented.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: He looks pale.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: If not,
Make use of this.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: There's anger in his eyes too:
His gesture, voice, behaviour, all new fashioned;
Well, if it does endure in act the trial
Of what in show it promises to make good,
Ulysses Cyclops, Io's transformation,
Eurydice fetched from hell, with all the rest
Of Ovid's fables, I'll put in your creed;
And for proof, all incredible things may be
Writ down that Lucio, the coward Lucio,
The womanish Lucio fought.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And lamorall,
The still employed great duellist lamorall.
Took his life from him.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Twill not come to that sure:
Methinks the only drawing of my sword
Should fright that confidence.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It confirms it rather.
To make which good, know you stand now opposed
By one that is your rival, one that wishes
Your name and title greater, to raise his;
The wrong you did, less pardonable than it is,
But your strength to defend it, more than ever
It was when justice friended it. The lady
For whom we now contend, Genevora
Of more desert, (If such incomparable beauty
Could suffer an addition) your love
To don Vitelli multiplied, and your hate
Against my father and his house increased;
And lastly, that the glove which you there wear,
To my dishonour, (Which I must force from you)
Were dearer to you then your life.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You'll find
It is, and so I'll guard it:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: All these meet then
With the black infamy, to be foiled by one
That's not allowed a man: to help your valour,
That falling by your hand, I may, or die,
Or win in this one single opposition
My mistress, and such honour as I may
Enrich my father's arms with.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis said nobly;
My life with them are at the stake.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: At all then. Fight.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: She's yours: this, and my life, to follow your fortune;
And give not only back that part the looser
Scorns to accept of —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: My poor life,
Which do not leave me as a further torment,
Having despoiled me of my sword, mine honour,
Hope of my lady's grace, fame, and all else
That made it worth the keeping.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I take back
No more from you, than what you forced from me;
And with a worser title: yet think not
That I'll dispute this, as made insolent
By my success, but as one equal with you,
If so you will accept me; that new courage,
Or call it fortune if you please, that is
Conferred upon me by the only sight
Of fair Genevora, was not bestowed on me
To bloody purposes: nor did her command
Deprive me of the happiness to see her
But till I did redeem her favour from you;
Which only I rejoice in, and share with you
In all you suffer else.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: This courtesy
Wounds deeper than your sword can, or mine own;
Pray you make use of either, and dispatch me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The barbarous Turk is satisfied with spoil;
And shall I, being possessed of what I came for,
Prove the more infidel?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You were better be so,
Then publish my disgrace, as 'tis the custom,
And which I must expect.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Judge better on me:
I have no tongue to trumpet mine own praise
To your dishonour: 'tis a bastard courage
That seeks a name out that way, no true born one;
Pray you be comforted, for by all goodness
But to her virtuous self, the best part of it,
I never will discover on what terms
I came by these: which yet I take not from you,
But leave you in exchange of them, mine own,
With the desire of being a friend; which if
You will not grant me, but on further trial
Of manhood in me, seek me when you please,
(And though I might refuse it with mine honour)
Win them again, and wear them: so good morrow. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I ne'er knew what true valour was till now;
And have gained more by this disgrace, than all
The honours I have won: they made me proud,
Presumptuous of my fortune; a mere beast,
Fashioned by them, only to dare and do:
Yielding no reasons for my wilful actions
But what I stuck on my sword's point, presuming
It was the best revenue. How unequal
Wrongs well maintained makes us to others, which
Ending with shame teach as to know ourselves,
I will think more on't.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Lamorall.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I came to seek you.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: And unwillingly;
You ne'er found me till now: your pleasure sir?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: That which will please thee friend: thy vow love to me
Shall now be put in action: means is offered
To use thy good sword for me; that which still
Thou wearest, as if it were a part of thee.
Where is it?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis changed for one more fortunate:
Pray you inquire not how.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Why, I ne'er thought
That there was music in't, but ascribe
The fortune of it to the arm.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Which is grown weaker too. I am not (In a word)
Worthy your friendship: I am one new vanquished,
Yet shame to tell by whom.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: But I'll tell thee
'Gainst whom thou art to fight, and there redeem
Thy honour lost, if there be any such:
The King, by my long suit, at length is pleased
That Alvarez and myself, with either's second,
Shall end the difference between our houses,
Which he accepts of I make choice of thee;
And where you speak of a disgrace, the means
To blot it out, by such a public trial
Of thy approved valour, will revive
Thy ancient courage. If you embrace it, do;
If not, I'll seek some other.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: As I am
You may command me.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Spoken like that true friend
That loves not only for his private end. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Genevora with a letter and Bobadilla.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: This from madonna Clara?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: Yes, and 't please you.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Alvarez daughter?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: The same, lady.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: She,
That saved my brother's life?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: You are still in the right,
She willed me wait your walking forth: and knowing
How necessary a discreet wise man
Was in a business of such weight, she pleased
To think on me: it may be in my face
Your ladyship not acquainted with my wisdom
Finds no such matter: what I am, I am;
Thought's free: and think you what you please.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: 'Tis strange,

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: That I should be wise, madam?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: No, thou art so;
There's for thy pains: and prithee tell thy lady
I will not fail to meet her: I'll receive
Thy thanks and duty in thy present absence:
Farewell, farewell, I say, now thou art wise. Exit Bob.
She writes here, she hath something to impart
That may concern my brother's life; I know not,
But general fame does give her out so worthy,
That I dare not suspect her: yet wish Lucio
Were master of her mind: but fie upon't;
Why do I think on him? see, I am punished for it,
In his unlooked for presence: now I must
Endure another tedious piece of courtship,
Would make one forswear courtesy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Gracious madam,
The sorrow paid for your just anger towards me
Arising from my weakness, I presume
To press into your presence, and despair not
An easy pardon.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: He speaks send: o strange.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And yet believe, that no desire of mine,
Though all are too strong in me, had the power
For their delight, to force me to infringe
What you commanded, it being in your part
To lessen your great rigour when you please,
And mine to suffer with an humble patience
What you'll impose upon it.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Courtly too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Yet hath the poor, and contemned Lucio, madam,
(Made able only by his hope to serve you)
Recovered what with violence, not justice,
Was taken from him: and here at your feet
With these, he could have laid the conquered head
Of Lamorall ('tis all I say of him)
For rudely touching that, which as a relic
I ever would have worshipped, since 'twas yours.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Valiant, and every thing a lady could
Wish in her servant.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: All that's good in me,
That heavenly love, the opposite to base lust,
Which would have all men worthy, hath created;
Which being by your beams of beauty formed,
Cherish as your own creature.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: I am gone
Too far now to dissemble: rise, or sure
I must kneel with you too: let this one kiss
Speak the rest for me: 'tis too much I do,
And yet, if chastity would, I could wish more.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: In overjoying me, you are grown sad;
What is it madam? by —
There's nothing that's within my nerves (And yet
Favoured by you, I should as much as man)
But when you please, now or on all occasions
You can think of hereafter, but you may
Dispose of at your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: If you break
That oath again, you lost me. Yet so well
I love you, I shall never put you to't;
And yet forget it not: rest satisfied
With that you have received now: there are eyes
May be upon us, till the difference
Between our friends are ended: I would not
Be seen so private with you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I obey you.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: But let me hear oft from you, and remember
I am Vitelly's sister.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.l: What's that madam?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Nay nothing, fare you well: who feels loves fire,
Would ever ask to have means to desire.Exeunt

div.head: Scaena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Assistente, Sayavedra, Anastro, herald, attendants.

sp.speaker: Assis.
sp.l: Are they come in?

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Assis.
sp.l: Read the proclamation,
That all the people here assembled may
Have satisfaction, what the Kings dear love,
In care of the republic, hath ordained;
Attend with silence: read aloud.

body.p: Forasmuch as our high and mighty master, Philip, the potent and most Catholic King of Spain, hath not only in his own royal person, been long, and often solicited, and grieved, with the deadly and uncurable hatred, sprung up betwixt the two ancient and most honourably descended houses of these his two dear and equally beloved subjects, don Ferdinando de Alrarez, and don Pedro de Vitelli: (All which in vain his majesty hath often endeavoured to reconcile and qualify:) but that also through the debates, quarrels, and outrages daily arising, falling, and flowing from these great heads, his public civil government is seditiously and barbarously molested and wounded, and many of his chief gentry (No less tender to his royal majesty than the very branches of his own sacred blood) spoilt, lost, and submerged, in the impious inundation and torrent of their still-growing malice: it hath therefore pleased his sacred majesty, out of his infinite affection to preserve his commonwealth, and general peace, from farther violation, (As a sweet and heartily loving father of his people) and on the earnest petitions of these arch-enemies, to order, and ordain, that they be ready, each with his well-chosen and beloved friend, armed at all points like gentlemen, in the castle of st. Jago, on this present Monday morning betwixt eight and nine of the clock; where (Before the combatants be allowed to commence this granted duel) this to be read aloud for the public satisfaction of his majesty's well-beloved subjects.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Hark how their drums speak their insatiate thirst
Of blood, and stop their ears 'gainst pious peace,
Who gently whispering, implores their friendship?

sp.speaker: Assis.
sp.l: Kings, nor authority can master fate;
Admit 'em then, and blood extinguish hate.

div.stage: Enter severally, Alvarez and Lucio, Vitelli and Lamora.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Stay, yet be pleased to think, and let not daring
Wherein men nowadays exceed even beasts,
And think themselves not men else, so transport you
Beyond the bounds of Christianity:
Lord Alvarez, Vitelli, gentlemen,
No town in Spain, from our metropolis
Unto the rudest hovel, but is great
With your assured valours daily proofs:
O will you then, for a superfluous fame,
A sound of honour, which in these times, all
Like heretics profess (With obstinacy)
But most erroneously, venture your souls,
'Tis a hard task, through a sea of blood
To sail, and land at heaven?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I hope not
If justice be my pilot: but my lord,
You know, if argument, or time, or love,
Could reconcile, long since we had shook hands;
I dare protest, your breath cools not a vein
In any one of us, but blows the fire
Which naught but blood reciprocal can quench.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Vitelli, thou sayst bravely, and sayst right,
And I will kill thee for't, I love thee so.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Ha, ha, old man: upon thy death I'll build
A story (With this arm) for thy old wife
To tell thy daughter Clara seven years hence
As she sits weeping by a winter fire,
How such a time Vitelli slew her husband
With the same sword his daughter favoured him,
And lives, and wears it yet: come lamorall,
Redeem thyself.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Lucio, Genevora
Shall on this sword receive thy bleeding heart,
For my presented hat, laid at her feet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thou talkest well lamorall, but 'tis thy head
That I will carry to her to thy hat:
Fie father, I do cool too much.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: O boy:
Thy fathers true son:
Beat drums, — and so good morrow to your lordship.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Brave resolutions.

sp.speaker: Anast.
sp.l: Brave, and Spanish right.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Lucio.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Vitelli.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Alvarez.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: How the devil
Got these cats into th' gutter? my puss too?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Hear us.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: We must be heard.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: We will be heard
Vitelli; look, see Clara on her knees
Imploring thy compassion: heaven, how sternly
They dart their emulous eyes, as if each scorned
To be behind the other in a look!
Mother, death needs no sword here: o my sister
(Fate fain would have it so) persuade, entreat,
A lady's tears are silent orators
(Or should be so at least) to move beyond
The honest tonged-rhetorician:
Why will you fight? why does an uncle's death
Twenty year old, exceed your love to me
But twenty days? whose forced cause, and fair manner
You could not understand, only have heard.
Custom, that wrought so cunningly on nature
In me, that I forgotten my sex, and knew not
Whether my body female were, or male,
You did unweave, and had the power to charm
A new creation in me, made me fear
To think on those deeds I did perpetrate,
How little power though you allow to me
That cannot with my sighs, my tears, my prayers
Move you from your own loss, if you shoal gain.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I must forget you Clara, till I have
Redeemed my uncle's blood, that brands my face
Like a pestiferous carbuncle: I am blind
To what you do: deaf to your cries: and marble
To all impulsive exorations.
When on this point, I have parched thy father's soul,
I'll tender thee this bloody reeking hand
Drawn forth the bowels of that murderer:
If thou canst love me then, I'll marry thee,
And for thy father lost, get thee a son;
On no condition else.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: Most barbarous.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Savage.

sp.speaker: Anast.
sp.l: Irreligious.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: O Lucio!
Be thou more merciful: thou bearest fewer years,
Art lately weaned from soft effeminacy,
A maiden's manners, and a maiden's heart
Are neighbours still to thee: be then more mild,
Proceed not to this combat; beest thou desperate
Of thine own life? yet (Dearest) pity mine
Thy valour's not thine own, I gave it thee,
These eyes begotten it, this tongue bred it up,
This breast would lodge it: do not use my gifts
To mine own ruin: I have made thee rich,
Be not so thankless, to undo me for't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Mistress, you know I do not wear a vain.
I would not rip for you, to do you service:
Life's but a word, a shadow, a melting dream,
Compared to essential, and eternal honour.
Why, would you have me value it beyond
Your brother: if I first cast down my sword
May all my body here, be made one wound,
And yet my soul not find heaven through it.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: You would be caterwauling too, but peace,
Go, get you home, and provide dinner for
Your son, and me: we'll be exceeding merry:
O Lucio, I will have thee cock of all
The proud vitelli's that do live in Sprine:
Fie, we shall take cold: hunch: — I am hoarse
Already.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How your sister whets my spleen!
I could eat Lucio now:

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Lamorall: you have often sworn
You'd be commanded by me.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Vitelli, brother,
E'en for your father's soul, your uncle's blood,
As you do love my life: but last, and most
As you respect your own honour, and fame,
Throw down your sword; he is most valiant
That herein yields first.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Peace, you fool.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why Lucio,
Do thou begin; 'tis no disparagement:
He's elder, and thy better, and thy valour
Is in his infancy.

sp.speaker: Gen
sp.l: Or pay it me,
To whom thou owest it: o, that constant time
Would but go back a week, than Lucio
Thou wouldst not dare to fight.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Lucio, thy mother,
Thy mother begs it: throw thy sword down first.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: I'll throw his head down after then.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Lamorall.
You have often swore you'd be commanded by me.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Never to this: your spite, and scorn Genevora,
Has lost all power in me:

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Your hearing for six words.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.l: Say. An. strange obstinacy!

sp.speaker: Al. Vit. Lu. Lam.
sp.l: We'll stay no longer.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Then by thy oath Vitelli,
Thy dreadful oath, thou wouldst return that sword
When I should ask it, give it to me, now,
This instant I require it.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: By thy vow,
As dreadful, Lucio, to obey my will
In any one thing I would watch to challenge,
I charge thee not to strike a stroke: now he
Of our two brothers that loves perjury
Best, and dares first be damned, infringe his vow.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Excellent ladies.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Pish you tyrannize.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: We did equivocate.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: On.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Then Lucio,
So well I love my husband, for he is so,
(Wanting but ceremony) that I pray
His vengeful sword may fall upon thy head
Successfully for falsehood to his sister.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: I likewise pray (Vitelli) Lucio's sword
(Who equally is my husband, as thou hers)
May find thy false heart, that durst gauge thy faith,
And durst not keep it.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: Are you men, or stone.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Men, and we'll prove it with our swords:

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Your hearing for six words, and we have done,
Zancho come forth — we'll fight our challenge too:Enter
Now speak your resolutions. Bobadilla with two swords and a pistol.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: These they are,
The first blow given betwixt you, sheathes these swords
In one another's bosoms.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: And rogue, look
You at that instant do discharge that pistol
Into my breast: if you start back, or quake,
I'll stick you like a pig.

sp.speaker: Alv
sp.l: — hold: you are mad.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: This we said: and by our hope of bliss
This we will do: speak your intents.

sp.speaker: Cla. Gen.
sp.l: Strike.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Shoot.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Vit. Lu. la. Hold, hold: all friends.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: Come down.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: These devilish women
Can make men friends and enemies when they list.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: A gallant undertaking and a happy;
Why this is noble in you: and will be
A well comer present to our master Philip
Then the return from his Indies. Enter Clara, Genevora Eugenia and Bobadilla.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Father your blessing.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Take her: if he bring not
Betwixt you, boys that will find out new worlds,
And win 'em too I'm a false prophet.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Brother.
There is a sister: long divided streams
Mix now at length, by fate.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I am not regarded: I was the careful steward that provided these instruments of peace, I put the longest weapon in your sister's hand, (My lord) because she was the shortest lady: for likely the shortest ladies, love the longest — men: and for mine own part, I could have discharged it: my pistol is no ordinary pistol, it has two ramming bullets; but thought I, why should I shoot my two bullets into my old lady? if they had gone, I would not have stayed long after: I would e'en have died too, bravely i'faith, like a roman-steward: hung myself in mine own chain; and there had been a story of Bobadilla, Spindola, Zancho, for after ages to lament: hum: I perceive I am not only not regarded, but also not rewarded.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Prithee peace: 'Shalt have a new chain, next
Saint Jaques day, or this new gilt:

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I am satisfied: let virtue have her due: and yet i am melancholy upon this atonement: pray heaven the state rue it not: I would my lord Vitelly's steward, and I could meet: they should find it should cost 'em a little more to make us friends: well, I will forswear wine, and women for a year: and then I will be drunk tomorrow, and run a whoring like a dog with a broken bottle at's tail; then will I repent next day, and forswear 'em again more vehemently: be forsworn next day again, and repent my repentance: for thus a melancholy gentleman doth, and ought to live.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: Nay, you shall dine with me: and afterwards
I'll with 'Ye to the King: but first, I will
Dispatch the castle's business, that this day
May be complete. Bring forth the malefactors. Enter Alguazier, Pachieco, Metaldi, Mendoza, Lazaril. Piorato. Malroda, and guard.
You Alguazier, the ringleader of these
Poor fellows, are degraded from your office,
You must restore all stolen goods you received,
And watch a twelvemonth without any pay:
This, if you fail of, (All your goods confiscate)
You are to be whipped, and sent into the galleys.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: I like all, but restoring that Catholic doctrine
I do dislike: learn all ye officers
By this to live uprightly (If you can)Exit.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: You cobbler, to translate your manners new,
Are doomed to th' cloister of the mendicants,
With this your brother; butcher there, for nothing
To cobble, and heel hose for the poor friars,
Till they allow your penance for sufficient,
And your amendment; than you shall be freed,
And may set up again,

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: Mendoza, come.
Our souls have trod awry, in all men's sight,
We'll underlay 'em, till they go upright. Exit. pach. And Mend.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: Smith, in those shackles you for your hard heart
Must lie by th'heels a year.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: I have shod your horse, my lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: Away: for you, my hungry white-loafed face,
You must to th' galleys, where you shall be sure
To have no more bits, than you shall have blows.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Well, though herrings want, I shall have rows.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: Signior, you have prevented us, and punished
Yourself severeller than we would have done.
You have married a whore: may she prove honest.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: 'Tis better my lord, than to marry an honest woman
That may prove a whore.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: 'Tis a handsome wench: and thou canst keep her tame:
I'll send you what I promised.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: Joy to your lordships.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Here may all ladies learn, to make of foes
The perfectest friends: and not the perfectest foes
Of dearest friends, as some do nowadays .

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Behold the power of love, to nature lost
By custom irrecoverably, passed the hope
Of friends restoring, love hath here retrieved
To her own habit, made her blush to see
Her so long monstrous metamorphoses,
May strange affairs never have worse success. Exeunt.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: Our author fears there are some rebel hearts,
Whose dulness doth oppose loves piercing darts;
Such will be apt to say there wanted wit,
The language low, very few scenes are writ
With spirit and life; such odd things as these
He cares not for, nor ever means to please;
For if yourselves a mistress or loves friends,
Are liked with this smooth play he hath his ends.

div.head: A prologue. At the reviving of this play.
div.l: Statues and pictures challenge price and fame;
If they can justly boast, and prove they came
From Phidias or Apelles. None deny,
Poets and painters hold a sympathy;
Yet their works may decay and lose their grace,
Receiving blemish in their limbs or face.
When the mind's art has this pre-eminence,
She still retaineth her first excellence.
Then why should not this dear piece be esteemed
Child to the richest fancies that ere teemed?
When not their meanest offspring, that came forth,
But bore the image of their father's worth.
Beaumont's, and Fletcher's, whose desert outweighs
The best applause, and their least sprig of bays
Is worthy Phoebus; and who comes to gather
Their fruits of wit, he shall not rob the treasure.
Nor can you ever surfeit of the plenty,
Nor can you call them rare, though they be dainty:
The more you take, the more you do them right,
And we will thank you for your own delight.
